soc.server

Class SOCLocalRobotClient

  • java.lang.Object
    • soc.server.SOCLocalRobotClient
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Runnable

    class SOCLocalRobotClient
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Runnable
    Each local robot in the SOCServer gets its own client thread. Equivalent to main thread used in SOCRobotClient when connected over the TCP network.

    This class was originally SOCPlayerClient.SOCPlayerLocalRobotRunner, then moved in 1.1.09 to SOCServer.SOCPlayerLocalRobotRunner. Split out in 2.0.00 to its own top-level class. Before 2.0.00, the thread name prefix was robotrunner- not localrobotclient-.

    Since:
    1.1.00
    Author:
    Jeremy D Monin <jeremy@nand.net>
    See Also:
    SOCServer.setupLocalRobots(int, int)

    • Field Detail

      • robotClients

        public static java.util.Hashtable<java.lang.String,SOCRobotClient> robotClients
        All the started SOCRobotClients. Key is the bot nickname.

        Note: If a bot is disconnected from the server, it's not removed from this list, because the same bot will try to reconnect. To see if a bot is connected, check SOCServer.robots instead.

        Since:
        1.1.13

      • robotClient

        final SOCRobotClient robotClient
        This bot's client in robotClients.

      • run

        public void run()
        Specified by:
        run in interface java.lang.Runnable

      • createAndStartRobotClientThread

        public static void createAndStartRobotClientThread(java.lang.String rname,
                                                   ServerConnectInfo sci,
                                                   java.lang.reflect.Constructor<? extends SOCRobotClient> cliConstruc3p)
                                            throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException,
                                                   java.lang.LinkageError,
                                                   java.lang.ReflectiveOperationException
        Create and start a robot client within a SOCLocalRobotClient thread. Optionally give it a copy of SOCServer.knownOpts or other Known Options. After creating it, yield the current thread (from caller) and then sleep 75 milliseconds, to give the robot time to start itself up. The SOCLocalRobotClient's run() will add the SOCRobotClient to robotClients.
        Parameters:
        rname - Name of robot
        sci - Server connect info (TCP or local) with robotCookie; not null
        cliConstruc3p - For a third-party bot client, its constructor with same parameters and behavior as SOCRobotClient.SOCRobotClient(ServerConnectInfo, String, String); null for built-in bots
        Throws:
        java.lang.LinkageError - for same reason as ClassNotFoundException
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if sci == null
        java.lang.ReflectiveOperationException - if there's a problem instantiating from a non-null cliConstruc3p
        Since:
        1.1.09
        See Also:
        SOCServer.setupLocalRobots(int, int)
